prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Claims for Breach of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: In order to bring a civil claim for breach of confidential business information, the plaintiff must be able to establish that the information in question is confidential business information. The definition of confidential business information is set out more comprehensively in Chapter 3. For purposes of this chapter, it may briefly be defined as business information which is the result of the expenditure of human effort, skill or money and which is in some way unique. It must not be known to others within the industry, and it must have been kept confidential by the party claiming relief for breach.
Actions for breach of confidential business information are fact-specific.[1] In order to bring a civil action, the plaintiff must establish that:
he or she has the sole right to benefit from the use of the information;[2]
the defendant has wrongly appropriated the information; and
the plaintiff has suffered damages as a result of the breach.[3]

If the plaintiff can prove these three facts on a balance of probabilities, an action for breach of confidential business information may be brought on a number of different grounds. Except in unusual circumstances (such as circumstances where the public has little interest) the court should not exercise its discretion to allow the action to proceed “under the cloak” of a confidentiality order.[4] Affidavits that disclose proprietary information, the disclosure of which would cause serious harm, may be treated as confidential.[5] It should be noted that these prerequisites must be established regardless of the type of action brought for breach of confidential business information.[6]
The wrongful actions of the defendant may be classified as:
breach of an express provision of a contract;
breach of an implied provision of a contract;
breach of confidence;
breach of fiduciary duty;
unjust enrichment;
wrongful interference with the contractual relations of others.

A court may grant relief based on more than one of these grounds.[7] Where a claim is based on any of these grounds, an action may be commenced in the superior courts of the provinces.[8] A trial judge's confidentiality order will not restrict the Court of Appeal from recovering documents subject to a confidentiality order.[9]
LAC Minerals Ltd. v. International Corona Resources Ltd. (1989), 61 D.L.R. (4th) 14, [1989] 2 S.C.R. 574; Guinan v. Northwestel Inc., [1997] N.W.T.R. 149 (S.C.).

See J.D. Kokonis, Q.C., J.R. Merrissey and A.A. Macelione, “Litigation as to Trade Secrets—Confidentiality Orders” in R.T. Hughes, ed., Trade Secrets (Toronto: The Law Society of Upper Canada, 1990), p. 143.

In Rodaro v. Royal Bank of Canada (2002), 59 O.R. (3d) 74, 157 O.A.C. 203, 22 B.L.R. (3d) 274 (C.A.), the court ruled that the disclosure of confidential information is actionable only if it results in detriment or damages to the confider or if it results in wrongful gain to the confident.
See Novopharm Ltd. v. Company X (2008), 60 C.P.C. (6th) 246 (F.C.).
See Danone Canada Inc. v. Canada (Attorney General), [2009] 4 F.C.R. 264.

Where the defendant can establish serious prejudice if the issues of liability and damages are not severed, disclosure may be ordered without a finding that the defendant misused confidential information: see 101055204 Saskatchewan Ltd. v. Wolfe (2008), 328 Sask. R. 42 (Q.B.).

Schauenburg Industries Ltd. v. Borowski (1979), 101 D.L.R. (3d) 701 at pp. 712–13, 25 O.R. (2d) 737 (H.C.J.), wherein damages were awarded for breach of fiduciary duty, use of confidential information and breach of contract.
MacDonald v. Vapor Canada Ltd. (1976), 66 D.L.R. (3d) 1, [1977] 2 S.C.R. 1344.
GasTOPS Ltd. v. Forsyth, 2011 ONCA 186.
